Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding the Contraction Biomechanics of Platelets at the Single-Cell Level

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1150235
lam

The goal of this project is to understand the contraction mechanics and dynamics of individual platelets, the blood cells responsible for the initiation of clot formation, in order to improve the fields of medicine and bioengineering. During the formation of blood clots, activated platelets interact with growing networks of fibrin polymers and contract against this fibrin scaffold. Although this platelet-driven clot retraction is known to be acto-myosin mediated, extremely little is known about the underlying biomechanical aspects of platelet contraction, due in part to technological limitations. Bulk assays of clot retraction exist but cannot directly measure platelet contractility at the single cell level, which is necessary to obtain a mechanistic understanding of the contraction process. In addition, as fibrin has recently been shown to have extremely complex material and mechanical properties, single platelet studies would enable the decoupling of the fibrin effects from platelets when examining the cellular biomechanics of clot formation. Therefore, a clear need exists for robust, single cell assays of platelet contraction. We recently published the first technique to achieve this goal using a modified atomic force microscopy system to directly and quantitatively measure the contraction mechanics and dynamics of single platelets. Although the atomic force micrscopy technique is highly sensitive, given the known wide physiologic heterogeneity and variability among individual platelets, the throughput must be improved to obtain a comprehensive understanding of the underlying cellular biomechanical mechanisms of platelet contraction. To those ends, Dr. Wilbur Lam and his laboratory will apply microfabrication techniques to develop a high-throughput "biomechanical flow cytometer" that simultaneously measures the contractility of multiple platelets in a single experiment. Then, Dr. Lam and his colleagues will quantitatively investigate the mechanistic relationship between the biomechanical and biological aspects of platelet contraction to obtain a comprehensive, cellular biomechanical understanding of that process.

The education objectives of this proposal are to: create a K-12 science outreach program for hospitalized children in which their own specific diseases are used as motivation and springboards for learning about science; use hospital-based supplies and equipment these children are accustomed to for hands-on science enrichment as part of this outreach; enable undergraduate and graduate students to implement this outreach program; and integrate cellular biomechanics concepts into this program, emphasizing that medicine is interdisciplinary and involves biology, physics, chemistry, and math.

Intellectual Merit: Clot formation occurs in three phases: 1) platelet aggregation at the site of injury, 2) formation of a fibrin polymer embedding platelets at that site, and 3) platelet-driven clot retraction/contraction. While the first two phases have been well characterized, extremely little is known about the last phase. As clots are exposed to a wide range of external forces in a hemodynamic environment and are spatially non-uniform, leading to a heterogeneity of mechanical microenvironments platelets might encounter, applying the concepts of cellular biomechanics to platelet contraction will vastly improve the overall basic understanding of clot formation. Indeed, our previous data suggest that platelet contraction is dependent on the mechanical properties of the underlying substrate. We will test the hypothesis that the mechanical microenvironment interacts with the known signaling pathways that mediate platelet contraction. To that end, we will build upon Dr. Lam's atomic force microscopy technique to enable the higher throughput experiments needed to quantitatively investigate the mechanics of platelet contraction.

Broader Impact: These will be the first reported experiments that quantitatively investigate the cellular biomechanics of platelet contraction and the results will significantly improve the overall understanding of platelet physiology and clot formation. In addition, these studies will have broad reaching implications as platelets are not only involved in clotting but also in numerous other biological processes (e.g., infections, inflammation, cardiovascular disease, stroke, and cancer) and the biocompatibility of implanted biomaterials. Diagnostics assessing platelet function are currently based only on platelet aggregation and as such, the proposed microsystem will form the basis for a new category of platelet function testing. Furthermore, the microsystem will potentially serve as a drug discovery platform for diseases associated with dysfunction in platelet contractility, such as cardiovascular disease and stroke. Combined with the innovative education program geared towards science education of hospitalized children, this interdisciplinary program will have a lasting impact on cellular biomechanics, basic hematology, and biomedical engineering, and biomaterials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF CAREER award was focused on the development of a novel microtechnology to study the muscle-like contractile properties of platelets, the cellular fragments in the blood responsible for clot formation after an injury under healthy circumstances and are implicated in diseases such as heart attacks and stroke.

An aspect of platelet physiology that we know remarkably little of is that they pull and contract like muscles. This contraction occurs when platelets are turned “on” and the nascent blood clot shrinks considerably as the platelets within it “smoosh” the clot from the inside. While this process has been known about for decades, remarkly little was known about the underlying biophysics of this process. For example, how “strong” is a platelet? How long does this process take and is it reversible? To that end, and during the course of this grant, our lab developed a microfluidic technology that enables measurement of these contraction forces generated by individual platelets at relatively high-throughput. Using techniques borrowed from the computer chip industry and the biomaterials fields, we invented a microdevice in which thousands of human blood platelets are perfused into the system and individual platelets are tracked by microscopy. Within the system are thousands of pairs of “microdots” of blood clotting proteins that platelets characteristically adhere to. Individual platelets are visualized as they adhere to one microdot and “reach over” to “grab” the other microdot (see accompanying image – an artistic rendering of our system). Since the mechanical properties of the surface are known, as each platelet contracts, the muscle-like contraction force is measured based on how much distance each platelet moves the dots together. Thousands of platelets are visualized simultaneously and therefore the contraction of each individual platelet is measured at the same time using this technique, which we call platelet contraction cytometry (PCC). Our PCC technology was presented in the journal Nature Materials. In addition to describing our PCC technique, we also discovered that platelets contract at higher forces when they are adhered to a stiffer substrate, demonstrating that platelets can “feel” the local physical properties of the clot to adjust their force of contraction, functioning like a finely tuned “micromachine.” Moreover, we discovered how this process works as well elucidated some of the important biological pathways that underlie this biophysical phenomenon.

During these studies, our group also discovered that the contractile forces are significantly different from platelet-to-platelet even within the same blood sample from the same patient. In addition, we discovered that a subpopulation of platelets that contract at relatively high levels is absent in the blood of some patients with chronic bleeding symptoms. Importantly, many of these bleeding patients have had significant clinical evaluations that have yielded only negative results and therefore are undiagnosed. As such, PCC may serve as a diagnostic marker that is independent of existing clinical tests. Importantly, our work involves the discovery of one of the first clinical biomarkers for potentially predicting or diagnosing diseases that is biophysical in nature.

Overall, our research for this grant focused on platelet biophysics and how platelets contract at the single cell level. This could lead to new categories of platelet diagnostics and help scientists identify new types of blood thinning drugs, which would modify how stiff platelets are or how they contract. Our work, which led to a better understanding of platelets’ physical properties will also inform treatment of other disorders such as inflammatory disorders, sickle cell anemia, and infectious processes.

NSF CAREER awards go to investigators in the early stages of their careers, who are working on transformative ideas in their fields while also striving to educate the next generation of scientists. As part of this project, we also developed a K-12 science outreach program for hospitalized children, in which the children’s own diseases are used as springboards and motivation for learning about science. Within this program, biomedical engineering undergraduates at Georgia Tech develop age-appropriate biology, physics, chemistry, and mathematics modules centered around chronic diseases children at Children’s Healthcare of Atlanta are hospitalized for. In the last several years, our program has serviced hundreds of our pediatric patients and has also been credited for enabling several of our patients to enter college as science, engineering, or math majors, and on the hand, for preventing several patients from dropping out.
